questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who is concerned about his delayed speech development and lack of social interactions. She reports that he does not respond when his name is called, avoids making eye contact, and prefers to play alone. The child has a particular interest in lining up his toy cars and becomes extremely upset with any change in routine. His play is repetitive, and he shows little interest in playing with other children. On examination, the pediatrician notes that the child does not follow pointing gestures and does not point at objects to show interest. Based on the clinical presentation, the pediatrician suspects autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Which of the following is a common clinical feature of ASD?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hyperactivity and impulsivity - These symptoms are more characteristic of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) than ASD. Although some children with ASD can display hyperactivity and impulsivity, these are not core features of ASD.
  • • Option A.
  • • Hyperactivity and impulsivity
  • • characteristic of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder
  • • Option B. Intellectual disability - While some individuals with ASD may also have intellectual disability , it is not a defining characteristic of ASD. Intellectual abilities in individuals with ASD can range from superior to severely challenged.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Intellectual disability
  • • individuals with ASD may also have intellectual disability
  • • Option D. Rapid language acquisition - This is not typically associated with ASD . In fact, individuals with ASD often experience delays in language development, and some may not develop significant spoken language.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Rapid language acquisition
  • • not typically associated with ASD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ ASD is characterized by challenges in social communication , repetitive behaviors , and in some cases, unusual responses to sensory stimuli , such as hypersensitivity or hyposensitivity . Recognizing these features is crucial for early diagnosis and intervention , which can significantly improve outcomes for children with ASD.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother due to concerns about his performance in school. His teachers report that he often seems to be "in his own world" during class, frequently fails to complete assignments, and is easily distracted by minor noises or movements in the classroom. At home, his mother notes that he forgets to do his chores, has difficulty organizing his tasks, and loses his school supplies regularly. During the evaluation, the boy frequently interrupts the conversation, fidgets in his seat, and struggles to wait his turn to speak. After a thorough evaluation, it is determined that the boy meets 7 of the 9 criteria for inattention according to the DSM-5 guidelines and displays several impulsive behaviors. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Give the child a 2-week trial of stimulant medication

options.label: C
options.text: Send the child for a complete psychoeducational assessment

options.label: D

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's developmental progress. The mother reports that her daughter began walking at 18 months, later than most children, and has recently started to lose the ability to use her hands effectively; she often wrings her hands together and has difficulty grasping toys. The child was noted to have microcephaly at her 12-month check-up, and her growth has remained below the 3rd percentile for her age. The pediatrician also notes a history of feeding difficulties, including poor suck and swallow coordination. Given the history of normal early development followed by regression in motor skills, loss of purposeful hand movements, and the presence of stereotypic movements, the pediatrician suspects Rett’s syndrome. Which of the following is a common clinical feature of Rett’s syndrome?

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Progressive loss of motor skills

Explanation:

  • • Option A. Delayed language development - While children with Rett’s syndrome may experience delays in language and communication skills , the most distinctive feature of the disorder is the regression in motor skills and the development of stereotypic hand movements.

  • • children with Rett’s syndrome
  • • delays in language
  • • communication skills
  • • Option B. Hyperactivity and impulsivity - These are not hallmark features of Rett’s syndrome and are more commonly associated with other disorders such as ADHD.

  • • not hallmark features of Rett’s syndrome
  • • Option C. Abnormalities in facial features - While some genetic syndromes are characterized by distinct facial features , Rett’s syndrome is not typically associated with specific abnormalities in facial features.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is referred to a psychiatric clinic by his school due to concerns about his behavior. Teachers and his parents report a pattern of aggressive outbursts, physical fights, and deliberate destruction of property. The boy has been caught stealing from classmates and lying about his actions on multiple occasions. His academic performance has declined over the past year, and he has been suspended several times for vandalism and fighting. The boy shows little remorse for his actions and tends to blame others for provoking him. His past medical history is unremarkable, and there is no evidence of a significant learning disorder or intellectual disability. Based on the boy's history of aggressive behavior, violation of social norms, and lack of empathy, the psychiatrist suspects a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by these features. Which of the following is a common clinical feature of the suspected disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Conduct disorder

  • • hyperactivity
  • • impulsivity
  • • core features of ADHD
  • • Option C. Dyslexia: This learning disorder is characterized by difficulties with accurate and/or fluent word recognition and by poor spelling and decoding abilities, not by aggressive or antisocial behavior.
  • • Option

  • • difficulties with accurate and/or fluent word recognition
  • • Option D. Autism spectrum disorder: ASD is characterized by difficulties in social communication and repetitive behaviors , but it does not typically include aggressive or antisocial behaviors as defining features unless in response to sensory overload or extreme stress.
  • • Option
  • • D. Autism spectrum disorder:
  • • difficulties in social communication and repetitive behaviors

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who is concerned about his frequent episodes of "daydreaming." She reports that during these episodes, which last several seconds and occur multiple times a day, her son appears completely disengaged and unresponsive to verbal cues. Outside of these episodes, the boy is described as attentive and capable of completing tasks without difficulty. His academic performance is satisfactory, and he is not known to be disruptive in the classroom. The mother is worried these episodes are affecting his learning and social interactions. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

options.label: B

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient pediatric department by his mother, who expresses concerns that her son might have Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). She describes him as being extremely restless at home, having a persistent inability to focus on tasks, and frequently misplacing his belongings. Despite these concerns, the child appears cooperative during the visit and his physical examination does not reveal any abnormalities. The mother is eager for advice on how to manage her son's symptoms and improve his ability to concentrate and remain organized. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Give the child a 2-week trial of stimulant medication

options.label: B

options.label: C

questions.text: A mother brings her child to the pediatric clinic concerned about developmental delays. The pediatrician recognizes this as a classic presentation of Phenylketonuria (PKU), a disorder characterized by an inability to metabolize phenylalanine, leading to its accumulation and subsequent neurotoxic effects. The psychologist observes the child's reading session and notes significant difficulty in decoding simple words, which impacts his reading fluency and comprehension.
